comment: <<An unexpecte d reply, typical of Alekhine! The logical reply would have been 12...Bxf6 and although Black would have been saddled with a backward king pawn, he would have had a tenable position. Bit the great Alekhine was never content with positions in which he had to be on the difensive; he always tried to steer into situations which created complications which might offer him winning chances, even though great risks were involved. The text move exposed Black's King to White's forces, but offered Black counter-maneuvers in the center>>. (Reshevsky)
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake by highlighting the strategic deficiency of the move, its potential risks, and the alternatives that could have been more favorable for Black.
